18.0: By the sweat of your face. Rabbi Yehudah HaChassid noted that not all men are subject to this curse whereas all women give birth in pain. This is because Chavah not only sinned, but also caused another to sin.

4.0: However (ach), of the blood. See Rashi. According to the Sages the word ach always limits the law it precedes. Thus in times of persecution a person is permitted to take his own life to avoid torture if he is afraid he will not be able to withstand his trial. However, some authorities argue with this.

25.0: On that very day. Literally, “In the strength of the day” — i.e. in the heat of the day. By comparison with the wording of Vayikra 23:28 the Sages derive that this was Yom Kippur. Avraham and his son … were circumcised. He called upon Shem to perform their circumcisions.

0.0: In the groves of Mamrei. See Rashi. Avraham asked him whether to perform the circumcision publicly or privately. Mamrei advised that he should do it publicly so that others would be inspired to emulate him.

12.0: When I am old. Hashem concealed from Avraham what Sarah had said about him to avoid creating tension between them. From this the Sages derive that it is permissible to lie for the sake of peace.

24.0: A reddish complexion. According to the midrash Yitzchok initially postponed Eisov’s circumcision because of his color. When he realized that this was his natural appearance he reasoned that since he was not circumcised at eight days, it was better to wait until he was thirteen, as Yishmael had been. But when Eisov turned thirteen, he refused to consent.

33.0: Eisov scorned the birthright. That is, he had already scorned it before this incident, which is why Yaakov resolved to acquire it from him. Rabbi Yehudah HaChassid derived from here that it is permissible to trick an evildoer into selling a mitzvah object that is in his possession.

28.0: Just as we did not touch you. They considered the mere fact that they did not harm him to be a great act of benevolence.

40.0: The mourning days … I will then kill. Or, “I will cause the mourning days for my father to approach if I kill my brother” — and therefore I will refrain until my father dies.

21.0: And he made a feast. His only intention was to get Yaakov drunk so that he would not notice that the deception. Thus when he gave him Rochel the following week, no feast is mentioned.

24.0: When it was morning. See Rashi. According to the midrash Yaakov asked, “Why did you answer when I called you “Rochel”? She replied, “Why did you answer your father when he called you “Eisov”? From that moment on he began to hate her.

7.0: Yaakov was very frightened. He was afraid that in the case of a conflict Eisov would enjoy the merit of the Holy Land. And distressed. He was distressed at being afraid after Hashem had promised to be with him (31:3).

16.0: Your signet ring. With this ring he actually betrothed her.

23.1: Let her be burned. Although there were no witnesses to the sin and she was not forewarned — both of which are required by Torah law — Yehudah wanted to make an example of her because of the generation’s loose morality.

44.1: Osnas. According to the Sages this was actually Dinah’s daughter by Shechem, who was transported to Egypt miraculously and raised by Poti Phera as a foundling.

0.0: Yaakov saw. Yoseif did not contact Yaakov earlier lest the thought of him as a slave and a prisoner cause him anguish; nor did he send word when be became ruler lest he refuse to believe it or lest the brothers flee in panic.

1.0: Yisrael gathered … and sat up. He did not wish to bless them lying down lest it be said that he was not in his right mind.
The physicians embalmed. After removing the waste from the body with foul chemicals they then infused it with a pleasant scent .
